Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Fire-Driven Alternative States and Spatial Variability in Forest Resilience at a Dry Forest Ecotone

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation project will investigate the drivers of forest gain and loss as well as tree regeneration and reburn severity in an area that is highly sensitive to environmental change - the dry forests on the eastern slopes of the Sierra Nevada Mountain of California. By examining vegetation change since 1950 at the lower margins of dry forest, and how these systems have changed in response to fires since 1986, the doctoral student will investigate the potential for fire-driven alternative states of forest and non-forest and how fine-scale spatial variability in topography and climate affect forest resilience. Given observed and predicted dry forest loss due to changes in temperature and increasing intensity and frequency of disturbances, determining where and when dry forests are likely to shift to an alternative state is critical to developing management plans to preserve forest cover. The results of this project will help guide management treatments such as prescribed fire, thinning and tree planting, by identifying portions of the landscape and conditions conducive to rapid vegetation change. This project will also enhance science training and education through participation of undergraduate students in field and laboratory work.

Future change in dry forest systems is likely to be abrupt and nonlinear, with severe disturbance potentially causing a conversion of forest to non-forest and positive feedbacks between disturbance and vegetation to some extent perpetuating the new mosaic of vegetation types. Ecotones, the boundary regions between ecosystems, are at the leading edge of change dynamics. This project will use aerial photographs to initially assess how the distribution of forest, woodland and steppe have changed at a forest/steppe ecotone since 1950, and relate shifts in distribution to topography, climate and disturbance history. Next, a network of field plots will be surveyed at the same sites in areas burned between 1987 and 2009 to evaluate post-fire tree regeneration and its drivers and the potential for fire-originated alternative vegetation states. Finally, remote sensing data on vegetation change, fire severity and disturbance history will be used to evaluate the potential for positive fire-vegetation feedbacks in areas burned twice since 1984 at the same ecotone. Insights gained from dry forest dynamics in the eastern Sierra Nevada through this project will be relevant to dry forest ecotones that are vulnerable to persistent fire-driven vegetation change elsewhere in the U.S. and around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As conditions become warmer and dryer and the number of large fires increases, wildfire is emerging as a key trigger of forest loss in semiarid regions. Such vegetation change is crucial to understand because dry forest loss affects biodiversity, water resources, carbon storage and climate. A growing body of research addresses the potential for fires to initiate and maintain vegetation change. Yet, the geography and timing of dry forest change and how it varies over complex terrain are still poorly understood.

We examined how terrain, climate, vegetation and fire interact to influence forest dynamics at the lower-elevation forest margin on the steep eastern side of the Sierra Nevada, California (Figure 1). This region contains a mix of fire-resistant and fire-sensitive tree species (Figure 2), and decades of fire exclusion have allowed forests to become denser and expand downslope. Increases in area burned and high-severity fire over the past 35 years have reshaped vegetation patterns in this region and suggest a potential for widespread and long-term forest loss caused by severe wildfire.

In the first of our three-part analysis we analyzed historical aerial photographs to determine how tree cover changed between 1950-2000.  We found a large increase in tree cover across all four study sites, Areas which gained more tree cover tended to be in locations in the landscape with higher moisture and higher tree cover. Moreover, areas of high tree cover gain tended to burn at higher severity in fires that burned between 2002-2008, suggesting increases in tree density over a half-century led to greater fire hazard.  

In the second portion of our analysis we quantified the spatial patterns of abundance of tree seedlings and saplings in the same study sites to determine how fire severity, climate, terrain and post-fire vegetation influence early post-fire forest recovery.  Productivity based on available moisture was crucial to tree regeneration, while drought stress was comparatively less important. The presence of nearby live trees that acted as a seed source was also crucial for post-fire tree regeneration. These results suggest that forests may be unable to recover following canopy killing fire, especially in drier portions of the landscape, but that forests may be resistant to future increases in drought stress if high-severity fire and  tree canopy loss can be avoided.

In the final part of our analysis, we assessed the influences of terrain, climate, vegetation and fire history on area burned and the spatial patterns of fire severity in the eastern Sierra Nevada. Although hot and dry conditions led to more area burned and more area of high severity fire, wetter conditions in prior years contributed to this pattern through increased fuel productivity.

Taken together, this project demonstrates how both fires and their absence can trigger change in dry forests. However, such change depends on existing vegetation patterns and on gradients in climate and water balance over complex terrain. Results from this project contribute to an understanding of mechanisms behind fire-driven vegetation change in Sierra Nevada dry forests and may have predictive value for rain-shadow forests more generally.
